comments.commentBody:
Betsy Grey, says, “Some people see this as romantic and Hemingway-esque,” she said. “I think it’s insane.”

Isn't that redundant?

I like some of Mr. B's recipes, but this was tmi (too much information). Makes him look foolish and authoritarian (well, he is, he wants to dictate to others). I'm not looking to govt. to tell me what to eat. I'm not overweight in the least. I eat what I please. I do eat very little canned (tomatoes, broths, and ceci beans) food and almost no "processed" food. Now and then I eat a pound of good chocolates or a bag of salty chips. I have no lifestyle diseases.

People have multiple sources for information. Govt. does not need to stick its many noses into "nutrition education." It's just an excuse to pile on more govt. employees. If "bad" food becomes more expensive, people may just cut back on "good" food (also taxed at 25% VAT!!!) Nanny state, no, thanks. This really diminishes my opinion of Mr. B.
I'm now considering moving to Denmark. If for no other reason than they, " have an administration that can deal with complicated stuff."
A great and good man and a true American hero.  He's home now.  Rest in peace, Reverend Shuttlesworth. And thank you.
Someone needs to remind Mr. Langone of Home Depot his customers are not the fat cats of the GOP....but the fixer-upper class.....they will not take this lightly.....
Difference between America and Europe: in Europe profits are for people, and in America, people are for profits.

What sad news. Fred Shuttlesworth's family has my deepest sympathies.
All these years later I am still awed by the courage of this man who sat, matched and was beaten next to Dr. King during the long war for civil rights and equality in the darkest days of Jim Crow segregation. It is a shame that his name is not as well known as Martin Luther King's. Hopefully with his passing we will begin to tell his story of courage, strength, love, compassion and wisdom.

God bless you Rev. Shuttlesworth!

Taxing to incentivize behavior is as old as time itself. Yet I think to tax (relatively) raw ingredients like butter and sugar is a mistake. There is a huge difference between buying a pound of butter to use in baking and cooking versus a frozen pizza. A responsible tax should target fats and sugars of the processed variety, and not discourage cooking from staple goods. The last thing we should do is discourage cooking.

So I agree that Election 2012 needs to be about both sides presenting a long-term vision for America. Where do we, as a country, want to be 5, 10, 25, 50 years from now. I write about the need for political leadership in the context of the debt limit debate in my blog: http://marqueepolitics.wordpress.com/2011/08/03/the-debt-ceiling-america...

Just another example of politics running wild and Obama can't control his own party.  The Sen Dems knew the Republican's would probably not pass the presidents plan so why not make them vote agains an add on of tax the rich.  No leadership in the White House.

Smoke screen antics taxing the 'rich'. Stop it !  We should downsize the government, especially all of the blotted agencies, better yet eliminate  them.  Then downsize the entitlements with deep cuts.  Support business so they can hire new workers, don't hurt them with more taxes.  Then vote out all of the fools in Washington who stand in the way of a sensible path forward.

Butter is a great reason to wake up in the morning. Since abandoning my low-fat vegetarian diet (eat real food, mainly plants NOT), I have happily lost 133 pounds. Saturated fats from grass-fed beef and wild salmon and free-range eggs are my daily companions and, to everyone's astonishment, the weight went but no wrinkles appeared (I'm 78; I was vegetarian for 60 years). Bittman and Brody write very well and I'm sure their mothers are quite proud of them but B & B are sadly misguided when it comes to nutrition.

A genius. A hero. A rebel. A disrupter. A cool guy in blue jeans and a turtleneck. A man who inspired us all and rocked the world. A person who was insanely great. More of a rock n' roller than anything else, in his own words: "“I grew up in the apricot orchards that later became known as Silicon Valley, and was lucky enough to have my young spirit infused with the social and artistic revolution of the day called rock and roll. It has never left me.”.

To honor Steve the rock star, a playlist has been lovingly put together, a combination of Steve's favorite bands and albums plus music in Apple commercials, developer conferences, and various Apple events. Hope you enjoy. Thank You Steve.

http://open.spotify.com/user/ehoffert/playlist/6qT013EgqLAltoneBVm5cE

See references on Steve's favorite albums: http://www.deathandtaxesmag.com/27063/steve-jobs-10-favorite-records-and...

and Apple products music:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_music_used_by_Apple_Inc.

I love the pic that Apple has posted, of Steve Jobs, on its website. He captures us with his eyes and makes it feel impossible to look away from him. Such as it was in life. He had the innate ability to bridge the gap between our want and need, between imagination and execution.

The greatest politicians of all time are dwarfed by this man.
Thanks Steve!
Or is that Eve?
Because of you, I bit the Apple!
For ever your'se!
Written on my MacBookPro!
A relic of your life.

As a graphic designer I am deeply grateful and have always been awestruck by Steve Jobs, and his partner Woz, who packed a type house, production studio, and a printing plant into a desktop computer and changed the way communication would be made and the speed at which it could be made.
Steve's continuing vision changed the way we think— and enabled us all to Think Differently.
He gave a great deal, set a great example, and I appreciate his vision for doing insanely great things that added so much to the world. I am deeply saddened by his death and extend my sympathies to his family and all at Apple and Pixar. — Stephen Goldstein

Steve Jobs was a great man. Few people in this world can say to have been indifferent to their technological creations. We shall all remember him as the great visionary of modern technology. No doubt, the history will give a special place among the greatest of mankind. Rest in peace, Steve. Our condolences to his family.

Wolf is not going to get his "GOP Purity" certified next year:
http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/11/24/gop-purity-test-would-hav_n_369...
I have been an Apple devotee from its very beginning, even at 600 bps!  However, Mr. Jobs' philanthropic "activities" will be forever a disturbing footnote.

I actually shed tears.

It’s a different world without Steve Jobs in it. A crappier world.

After the passing of my stepdad earlier this year, my sister and I went to clean out his house and I found my Macintosh 128K, the first Mac, which I had been storing there. I bought it in 1984, when they first came out. It had been sitting there, unused, for years.

I brought it home, and hooked everything up. It actually booted up and was usable, which is pretty remarkable for a computer, or any device, but most especially a computer, almost thirty years on.

That in itself could be a testimony to Steve Job’s ideals.

A computer that is almost thirty years old, “just works.”

He was never ready to settle for good enough. He always wanted to be better.

Steve Jobs was clearly a creative powerhouse and a technological innovator, but did he really change people's lives as many of the commenters here would suggest?  I feel that this adulation is a bit excessive for someone who was essentially a purveyor of fashionable goods.  However, considering the deeply materialistic and consumerist nature of our society where product worship reigns supreme and accumulation of lucrative goods is often considered a worthy goal in and of itself, the deification of someone like Jobs is not surprising.  By comparison, the death of someone who genuinely changed lives for the better, Wangari Maathai, garnered scant acknowledgement from the establishment media and general population alike.  Am I the only one who sees this as a problem?

Steve Jobs passing is sad because it reminds us life is short and his has been shortened. But he followed his heart and intuition and made a great and lasting contribution to humanity. He has been a light of the technological age and will be remembered as one of the great minds that influenced and changed life on this planet. May his soul rest in peace and may his family and the Apple family find comfort with the thought and memory that his life has been such a great blessing to humanity.

I just printed a 30 page article from Bloomberg to go along with other credible articles about Perry and the Koch Bros. and their million dollar donor club. The title of the Bloomberg article is Koch Brohters Flout Law Getting richer with Secret Iran Sales. Well worth the paper and ink.

Those among us who are (still) normal are not exactly thrilled with this announcement. In addition to hostility to every opinion not corresponding to his own, Fischer invents American history and has successfully insulted every minority as well as women.  Since he does not regard Mormons as Christians and insists the First Amendment protects only Christians, perhaps Romney is very brave indeed:  a Daniel in the Lions' Den.

its about time the democrats took the initiative to not raise the taxes on the very rich but to restore them to where they were when bush reduced them.
the young are beginning to wake up to the manipulations of wall street and big companys executives to control the financal and the job market.y control trillions of dollars that should be used to help the middle income familes.
